context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: The first that inland waters and coast line are -- especially inland waters is a term which has meaning in international relations.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: That's where people talk about it.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Now, the only other place I know where they talk about it is in a certain number of insurance policies speak of inland waters and I can't find in the ordinary places of looking any other references of inland waters.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Oh, they do that Justice Brennan, this morning are already mentioned another place where it's relevant.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: That's true.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: I -- it where there it is a term that is sort of defined by the very Act itself.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What you're telling us is that you abandoned that agreement or perhaps not abandoned it but it's no longer relevant you say because the Submerged Lands Act proceeding on a different premise?

context.speaker: Richard H. Keatinge
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Richard H. Keatinge
context.text: We say that because the premise in the basic law which is now applicable has changed the Master's premise is no longer applicable.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, may I get back to Mr. Justice Goldberg's question, you actually did put in, I gather, a great deal of this data.

context.speaker: Richard H. Keatinge
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Although, he rejected it and therefore didn't evaluate it.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: You would have something you hope to put your anchor down to pretty soon it becomes a well precedence and pretty soon it becomes uniform authority.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: There aren't any such decisions as that.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: There are a few cases referring to the problem but then there is very clearly Justice Brennan of course the usage in United States against California.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, what I'm really getting at is this, Mr. Justice Black said in the initial case speaking of Collard.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In doing so it has used the language strong enough to indicate.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court then believes that States not only own titled lands of soil but the navigable inland waters but also owned soil under all navigable waters within their territorial jurisdiction whether inland or not?

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: The first that inland waters and coast line are -- especially inland waters is a term which has meaning in international relations.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: That's where people talk about it.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Now, the only other place I know where they talk about it is in a certain number of insurance policies speak of inland waters and I can't find in the ordinary places of looking any other references of inland waters.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Oh, they do that Justice Brennan, this morning are already mentioned another place where it's relevant.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: That's true.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: I -- it where there it is a term that is sort of defined by the very Act itself.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What you're telling us is that you abandoned that agreement or perhaps not abandoned it but it's no longer relevant you say because the Submerged Lands Act proceeding on a different premise?

context.speaker: Richard H. Keatinge
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Richard H. Keatinge
context.text: We say that because the premise in the basic law which is now applicable has changed the Master's premise is no longer applicable.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, may I get back to Mr. Justice Goldberg's question, you actually did put in, I gather, a great deal of this data.

context.speaker: Richard H. Keatinge
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Although, he rejected it and therefore didn't evaluate it.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: You would have something you hope to put your anchor down to pretty soon it becomes a well precedence and pretty soon it becomes uniform authority.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: There aren't any such decisions as that.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: There are a few cases referring to the problem but then there is very clearly Justice Brennan of course the usage in United States against California.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, what I'm really getting at is this, Mr. Justice Black said in the initial case speaking of Collard.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In doing so it has used the language strong enough to indicate.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court then believes that States not only own titled lands of soil but the navigable inland waters but also owned soil under all navigable waters within their territorial jurisdiction whether inland or not?

All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, Ne.speaker: Justice Stewart
All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, Ne.case_name: All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad Company
All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, Ne.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 21, 1964

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: Now obviously, the gross revenue -- it caused the railroad to handle that four million pounds and the Commission recognized this because it said, and I read from page 12 of the printed record here, “Thus for this period” and the Commission was referring to the 11-week period, “the respondent”, that's the New Haven, “moved over four million pounds of additional traffic in return for $129 of added revenue.

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: This represents less than one-third of ascending revenue for each additional 100 pounds of traffic moved.”

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: The Commission then referred to the fact that the evidence respecting costs --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well that -- that's not a holding that they lost money necessarily and depending on Justice White's question but merely a suggestion that maybe they didn't make as much money.

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: That the -- true, true.

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: They lost money.

All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, Ne.speaker: Justice Brennan
All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, Ne.case_name: All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad Company
All States Freight, Inc. v. New York, Ne.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 21, 1964

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: So that -- so if you had a 70,000 pound shipment of two commodities with the 60% provision and you'd have 42,000 pounds would be the most that one of them could weigh.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Yes, but then I gather the balance could be in a 95 or a hundred different thing.

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: True.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, how does that differ on these boxcars and so I think Justice Black and I would dissent of it?

context.speaker: Homer S. Carpenter
context.text: These rates have no such restriction at all.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: So you can have a hundred different items or a single item?

American Committee for Protection of For.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 09, 1964

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: That's right, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: There's a concept of -- this has to be a cover as I -- the Ian Fleming used to call it --

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Or a front, it has to -- it purport -- purportedly to be per as Justice Harlan says for Abraham Lincoln but really to be --

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: That's right (Voice Overlap).

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: And insofar as we talked --

context.speaker: Ewell Lee Smith, Jr.
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What actually happened here, that whether they complied as they should have or not, that they did at least attempt to comply with the rule laid down in the case of this (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Ewell Lee Smith, Jr.
context.text: Which case, Your Honor?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case that Mr. Justice Stewart --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Lee and Purvin.

context.speaker: Ewell Lee Smith, Jr.
context.text: Lee and Purvin?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: The law of Texas say, "You should never have that kind of original trial again", even though the -- either the -- there was no notice given in the first case.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: He can't have it because the burden is on the other person -- becomes on you when it wouldn't have been at first.

context.speaker: William Duncan
context.text: That shifting of the burden resulted in this case but --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Well, that -- whatever it's resulted from, the result is that it resulted because of your law down there as I understand it which is as Mr. Justice Stewart read from the record.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But you have it, a situation where if this judgment ignored the lack of notice as I don't mind saying, I have -- instead of a belief, its probably is, the result is that the -- you didn't give him the same kind of trial he would've had gotten, same kind of it then take his trial had he been the defendant in the original case.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: He couldn't get it that way because he became in effect the moving party in a new trial.

Atlantic Refining v. Federal Trade Commi.speaker: Justice Clark

Atlantic Refining v. Federal Trade Commi.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 30, 1965

context.speaker: Frederic L. Ballard, Jr.
context.text: That is precisely what they do, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Frederic L. Ballard, Jr.
context.text: They say that the -- they at least requires that handling of TBA, it does not require the handling of any particular kind.

context.speaker: Frederic L. Ballard, Jr.
context.text: And all oil companies to meet these legitimate needs that I described, all of the oil companies with any size, whatsoever, provide TBA programs for the dealers.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: But the -- as I read the Commission order, it doesn't concern itself with the proposition that Justice Goldberg mentioned?

context.speaker: Frederic L. Ballard, Jr.
context.text: The Commission's order does not concern itself, but that is correct Your Honor.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: It concerns itself was pressure by Atlantic like threats to cancel or renew at least if he doesn't take a particular supplier's product?

Atlantic Refining v. Federal Trade Commi.speaker: Justice Clark
Atlantic Refining v. Federal Trade Commi.case_name: Atlantic Refining v. Federal Trade Commission
Atlantic Refining v. Federal Trade Commi.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 30, 1965

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: No, they merely signed it up and didn't do anything, but I think that the plan - I think that the - the contract requires them to use these powers.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: The record shows they have used the power.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: [Inaudible] what I'm reading from B37 of the Appendix which is the part where they mentioned [Inaudible] Now do I read this wrong?

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: It's in reference to the question that Mr. Justice White just asked.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Do I read this wrong?

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: I thought the Commission would merely holding that in effect entering into a sales contract with a major oil company commission contract with a major oil company is a per se violation.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Esta.speaker: Justice Brennan
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Esta.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Estate of Noel
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Esta.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 01, 1965

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: [Inaudible] that form of life insurance is taken out, but the fact that they've said it.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: For example the ordinary tuition plan for instance, I expect many received, which provides that if you don't pay tuition plan over the course of the full year because of death that the obligation is distinguished, but the bank is paid by the insurance company.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What's the economic interest in say passing, if it makes that passing?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I think you answered to Justice Stewart earlier that, that would be passable?

context.speaker: Harry Norman Ball
context.text: I did sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: What is the term?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: What I'm asking in that case is, is there a contrary to that?

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: They are the government people who told these certain things --

context.speaker: Ralph L. Roy
context.text: -- probably on the question of willful -- intentionally or willfully if a person or a crowd did willfully commit a crime but these people came down for the violative and the same purpose of protest in illegal arrest and they came to the courthouse and I think they necessarily violated, the reason is rather clear.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Roy, earlier in your argument, Mr. Justice Black raised this question.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: These people were -- this man for one course of conduct was convicted of three distinct and separate offenses and sentenced to three distinct punishments accumulatively imposed as any claim had been made during the course of these proceedings that this was constitutionally offensive?

context.speaker: Ralph L. Roy
context.text: No issue made of course with reference to jeopardy.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Pope, as I understand your basic argument is that Alabama can, if it chooses, decide to enforce part but not all of the liability created by Georgia.

context.speaker: Max C. Pope
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And to see what's been suggested, if I understand, also by Justice Black's question.

context.speaker: Max C. Pope
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, now, I'm assuming you're right on that for the purposes of these -- that this question which expresses my doubt.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In the case.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now, does that extend the jurisdiction or not?

context.speaker: R. Foster Etheredge
context.text: No, I don't --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Black asked you a moment ago that let's assume that you would come in here and had litigated the jurisdiction and had lost.

context.speaker: R. Foster Etheredge
context.text: No, sir, it would not decide it.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, I know, but let's assume that you had come in, pleaded that -- pleaded Singleton against Hope and the lower court refused to go with you.

context.speaker: R. Foster Etheredge
context.text: It applied to Georgia law.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: How do we know that?

context.speaker: R. Foster Etheredge
context.text: Because it says in the complaint.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: How do you know that it didn't adopt it, just as Mr. Justice Brennan said?

context.speaker: R. Foster Etheredge
context.text: Well, it says that only paper pleading before it is the claims that under the law of Georgia, and the judgment reveals and reflects that he had to administer the law of Georgia.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: That he had what?

Department of Mental Hygiene of Californ.speaker: Justice White
Department of Mental Hygiene of Californ.case_name: Department of Mental Hygiene of California v. Kirchner
Department of Mental Hygiene of Californ.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 19, 1965

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: (Inaudible) -- here is the Attorney General of California saying that you're entirely wrong when you say that all patients of state mental hospital such as Agnews are -- and must be dangerously insane.

context.speaker: Alan A. Dougherty
context.text: So, they say it but Your Honor, there's no authority to support this position.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I know.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But all you're doing is asking us sort of a -- as Mr. Justice Stewart says to decide this question of the California law when the Attorney General comes in here and says you're wholly wrong in your assertion about who may enter this hospital.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Then he --

context.speaker: Alan A. Dougherty
context.text: We --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Then what -- what was the -- the plea that was held now barred?

context.speaker: Leon Hubert, Jr.
context.text: It's -- all it does is say that the evidence may not be produced, that's all.

context.speaker: Leon Hubert, Jr.
context.text: And the plea of res judicata has no effect on that either so that the only reason why the State can proceed in this --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, I'm as confused as Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: If -- if the appeal fails as related to this res judicata or whatever it is --

context.speaker: Leon Hubert, Jr.
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Paul T. Gish, Jr.
context.text: I can only come in then by asking a question, what evidence?

context.speaker: Paul T. Gish, Jr.
context.text: There's none of the questions had been answered.

context.speaker: Paul T. Gish, Jr.
context.text: There was no testimony at all from Loyd except in name and they had a difficult time in getting him to state his name.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: But what if the -- wouldn't the objection that he made -- as read by Mr. Justice Stewart carrying objection to this entire line of testimony and the judge having overruled it, wouldn't he be entitled to believe that he had made his objection adequately?

context.speaker: Paul T. Gish, Jr.
context.text: If we admit that Mr. Chief Justice and in a sense, we have to admit that except as I said, none of the questions were ever answered.

context.speaker: Paul T. Gish, Jr.
context.text: There was nothing in evidence where we had the questions before the jury and it was virtually read in evidence.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: They couldn't see and hear what?

context.speaker: John D. Cofer
context.text: What was going on at the trial because I would have the jury moved while I was making the objection so this juror sent this affidavit.

context.speaker: John D. Cofer
context.text: Now it seems from that, that the television or something was so affecting counsel in the defense of his client, that he is making a very poor impression from the jury.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Cofer, you -- you didn't answer Mr. Justice Clark's question.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You said that the -- there was no live broadcast from the courtroom during this trial.

context.speaker: John D. Cofer
context.text: No words broadcast.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: You said that the -- there was no live broadcast from the courtroom during this trial.

context.speaker: John D. Cofer
context.text: No words broadcast.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now Mr. Justice Clark asked you the question when was it broadcast and how?

context.speaker: John D. Cofer
context.text: Well at the preliminary hearing, it was fully brought --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Nobody is talking about --

context.speaker: Leon Jaworski
context.text: The problem there would have been Mr. Justice Brennan whether any of that information would have reached the jury.

context.speaker: Leon Jaworski
context.text: I do think you'd have a different problem, yes.

context.speaker: Leon Jaworski
context.text: But as it was pointed out to the Chief Justice, in answer to Mr. Chief Justice Warren's question, there actually was a complete segregation of this jury from all outside like --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well that does suggest then doesn't it to what Mr. Justice Stewart said.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: My problem here is not whether Canon 35 is a constitutionally ruled, it's whether in the circumstances these applied.

context.speaker: Leon Jaworski
context.text: I think that's right.

context.speaker: John W. Douglas
context.text: So that I think here, one can also see that there was a total failure to meet the initial standard of showing that there was some kind of substantial injury to private interest concerned.

context.speaker: John W. Douglas
context.text: Had they made such a showing?

context.speaker: John W. Douglas
context.text: Then of course the question would have arisen whether the public interests involved in a disclosure on the record of this information was outweighed by those private interests, but there was no showing of private injury by the respondents.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Douglas, if -- if you prevail here as I understand it, it would be your thought, if I understood your answer to Mr. Justice Goldberg, a question by Mr. Justice Goldberg that the -- on the -- on the, on -- in the future hearings now before the Commission, this respondent could protect himself by refusing to answer any given question or by refusing to produce any -- any given thing that might have -- might be subpoenaed and then when he test that seriatim one by one with the Court or would they wait until it was all over and then deal with the Court -- or what --

context.speaker: John W. Douglas
context.text: The --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: -- what would the procedure be?

Federal Trade Commission v. Colgate-Palm.case_name: Federal Trade Commission v. Colgate-Palmolive Company
Federal Trade Commission v. Colgate-Palm.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1964

context.speaker: Philip B. Heymann
context.text: Justice Goldberg's suggestion by the way I take it takes you right out of the order.

context.speaker: Philip B. Heymann
context.text: That doesn't take another order Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Philip B. Heymann
context.text: It takes you right out of it.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: What Justice Goldberg read wouldn't be truth?

context.speaker: Philip B. Heymann
context.text: That it was a reproduction?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It's a reproduction of an actual test.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Paul Rodgers
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Paul Rodgers
context.text: Yes sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: On the other hand, if he gets the entire vote in his own district in Justice Brennan's example, if he gets all 10,000 votes in his district, he would lose if everybody in the other two districts (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Paul Rodgers
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It could work the other way around, he could lose all 10,000 in his own district and yet by the 20,000 of the other two were elected.

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: -- that the film was shown.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well in that case, then it was just a matter in this case; it's just a matter of paying the $30.

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: Well, I think that -- in -- in -- in effect, I think the State of Maryland would concede 90 -- every film that's licensed is constitutionally unobjectionable which would entail 99.7% of all prints submitted to that Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And you've also said I think in answer to Mr. Justice Goldberg's earlier question that you would concede that I mean a municipality or a state could impose a business tax on -- on -- on a movie theater.

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: Yes, I would not concede that this is a business tax, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: If -- if the State of Maryland were to enact the tax, that anyone who submits $25 can have his film -- can get a license for whatever purpose.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And that he suffers a penalty only if it's something that might be suppressible as obscene or otherwise, isn't -- basically, isn't that your position?

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: That is our position, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: If this Court finds that --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Yes but if that is your position, Mr. Bilgrey, I have the same difficulty as Mr. Justice Goldberg has.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Why that -- if we will -- are to agree with that, why that doesn't involve overruling Times Film?

context.speaker: Felix J. Bilgrey
context.text: Well of course, I would welcome --

General Motors Corporation v. District o.speaker: Justice White
General Motors Corporation v. District o.case_name: General Motors Corporation v. District of Columbia
General Motors Corporation v. District o.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 10, 1965

context.speaker: Henry E. Wixon
context.text: I said --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, what was -- you said it twice now and I still don't understand it.

context.speaker: Henry E. Wixon
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Your answer to Mr. Justice Goldberg's question is --

context.speaker: Henry E. Wixon
context.text: I said that if -- that it was difficult for me to deal with hypothetical extremes such as the one which has been --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What if -- if it were clearly shown that you were -- that part of the income you were taxing was earned outside the district, didn't you answered -- say to me a while ago that you might well have to find another way of taxing General Motors?

Gillespie v. United States Steel Corpora.speaker: Justice Stewart
Gillespie v. United States Steel Corpora.case_name: Gillespie v. United States Steel Corporation
Gillespie v. United States Steel Corpora.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 13, 1964

context.speaker: Thomas V. Koykka
context.text: Now I concede of course, that this Court being the Supreme Court can declare that under the Jones Act there is liability without fault, but I do not believe the Court can do it and remain faithful and consistent either to the language of the statute, to this Court's cases or to history on this point.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Koykka?

context.speaker: Thomas V. Koykka
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Goldberg's question suggests to me a less theoretical, perhaps less theoretical but more of a practical question.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: How much practical importance does this first question have in view of the broad reading that this Court has given in FELA cases to default and to negligence from a very liberal to the very minimal that it's -- as it has required?

context.speaker: Thomas V. Koykka
context.text: That is to say how important is the distinction as to whether negligence --

context.speaker: Albert W. Harris, Jr.
context.text: Well, that's -- that certainly may be Your Honor but I think it's also clear from that opinion, from the majority opinion in that case that the Court did not and certainly it did not say and did not imply that the comment rule would violate the Fifth Amendment --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Oh.

context.speaker: Albert W. Harris, Jr.
context.text: -- if the Fifth Amendment were applicable to the states.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Your -- I think you and Mr. Justice Harlan are not far apart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: You --

context.speaker: Albert W. Harris, Jr.
context.text: I think --

context.speaker: Albert W. Harris, Jr.
context.text: You cannot presume or infer guilt as such from the failure to testify.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: But whatever words you used is -- taken in court is (Inaudible) get from it is the fact that he didn't testify, he took advantage of the constitution of privilege and take -- takes advantage of it (Inaudible) conviction.

context.speaker: Albert W. Harris, Jr.
context.text: We feel that's going to be the result Your Honor under any rule you'll hand down.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, Mr. Harris didn't you answer a little (Inaudible) to Justice Black's question?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It's your con -- are you conceding here that California's only interest is to convict these people?

context.speaker: Albert W. Harris, Jr.
context.text: No, we -- I --

context.speaker: Thomas I. Emerson
context.text: They're under the counter, but there's no problem in obtaining them if you ask for them.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: It's not done --

context.speaker: Thomas I. Emerson
context.text: Certain devices must be sold on physician's prescription, of course, and can be obtained only on prescription from a physician, but others which do not require such a prescription can be obtained without it at the drugstore.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I'd like to ask you a question in connection with Justice Brennan's question.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I can understand an argument, from my own constitutional ideas, based on equal protection.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: It seems to me what someone has done here deliberately is to try to force a decision on the broadest possible grounds of the meaning of due process speaking as a matter of substance, and to have us weigh the facts and circumstances as to the advisability of a law like this, rather than leave it up to the legislature.

context.speaker: Joseph B. Clark
context.text: Not all people are immune from adultery.

context.speaker: Joseph B. Clark
context.text: The problem would be greater, the problem of identification, the problem of conviction, would be greater without it.

context.speaker: Joseph B. Clark
context.text: I don't hold that the statute is the most wise way of putting the decision.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But as Justice Goldberg said, you do have substantive criminal statutes against adultery or against extramarital fornication, or non-marital fornication, in Connecticut, don't you?

context.speaker: Joseph B. Clark
context.text: That is correct.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And you're suggesting, as a matter of practical problems of proof, it's easier to prove that in such relationship people use contraceptives than it is to prove that they had such a relationship?

context.speaker: Daniel R. McLeod

context.speaker: Daniel R. McLeod

context.speaker: Daniel R. McLeod

context.speaker: Daniel R. McLeod

context.speaker: Constance Baker Motley
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Constance Baker Motley
context.text: You may be guilty of a civil trespass but I don't think you can be punished on the statute which required you in plain language to be ordered to leave the premises.

context.speaker: John M. Harlan
context.text: I just wanted to get your point, that's it.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible) problems with this case, the problem here are the facts, assuming the statute requires a situation put by Justice Harlan.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And with these facts (Inaudible) to leave the premises, this is the thing that bothers me.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: Permanent registration became a practical institution there.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: That means that once a voter is registered in the first place he remains on the registration role until he dies or moves away or take some voluntary action to have himself removed.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: As a practical matter, his name remains there for many years.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Mr. Carter, in reference to Justice Douglas' question, if the man is registered and then pays the poll tax, permanently registered and then pays the poll tax then he doesn't have to file the certificate and he's now required by those who do not pay the poll tax because if the federal officer they want to vote for, is that correct?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Am I correct in that?

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: Yes Mr. Justice Goldberg that is generally correct.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: Either witness or another act, that is in accord with the forms that we viewed in Virginia for many years in absentee voting and voting by persons absent in the armed services.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: In fact, the certificate is patterned very closely on the certificate that has been used by armed service voters for many years in Virginia.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Well, the question that was asked by Mr. Justice White doesn't mean or your answer to it rather, doesn't mean that there is a form that they must fill out in paying the poll tax which will give the same information, is that -- the certificate does it?

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: There is no form or return that is required in connection with payment of the poll tax itself.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: So it does not make the classification.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: Now we did say in our reply brief that even conceding that it made a classification of federal voters, that classification would be invalid under the rule of Pope versus Williams, a Maryland case which was cited and relied on very heavily by this Court only yesterday in the case of Carrington versus Rash.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: And we believe that under the language of both of those cases, this particular provision of Virginia Code would be valid as a classification even if it did -- even if it were limited to federal voters only which is not --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, as Mr. Justice Harlan had suggested it's a classification of the Twenty-fourth Amendment itself makes, is it not?

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: That is quite correct and many of the enactments of the General Assembly in 1963 were classificate -- bringing into law the classifications of the Twenty-fourth Amendment made.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Carter, Jr.
context.text: Now, in answer to the contention made by the Government, the questions of Mr. Justice Harlan and Mr. Justice White got right at the heart of their contention because if you read their brief, you will see that what they are saying is that anything which is burdensome, onerous, harsh, oppressive, and which would force you to pay the poll tax would be invalid under the Twenty-fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: G. Garland Lyell, Jr.
context.text: Thought I didn't think though.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Turning back [Inaudible]

context.speaker: G. Garland Lyell, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: Going back to Justice Black's question, the Court didn't in the second opinion say that they would have stopped a [Inaudible] and they have a theory to stop.

context.speaker: G. Garland Lyell, Jr.
context.text: In addition to the failure to object.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: On the grounds --

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Would you say that denied in due process?

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee
context.text: I'm inclined to think they would infringe, I retrace my steps.

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee
context.text: I'm inclined to think they would get off the close, but as I say I would hate to put myself in the position of saying that now because we never had to pass on that question yet.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But here, let's take this case which is certainly not the case at bar but following what Justice Black had said. Supposing in the privacy of the chambers, the judge were to say to a lawyer, you will pay me a $1,000, I'll decide the case in your favor, that's about the worst thing I'm sure you'll agree with me, any judge could do.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Now suppose the next day the lawyer filed a petition for disqualification saying, you asked for a bribe and therefore, I want to disqualify you.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: There is no supporting affidavit because there is no disinterested person who overheard that conversation.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee
context.text: On page 5 it does of the transcript, it does not indicate who was present.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Alright then, if it doesn't indicate who was present, why isn't the situation exactly like the hypothetical that Mr. Justice Goldberg just stated?

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee
context.text: In other words, why it did not present a justiciable question that own his bare allegation?

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: It's a single -- single individual, you said on in the hypothetical Mr. Justice Goldberg gave you, you said the reason that that case should be differentiated from this was because this man in that case was the only person who knew that fact, because he and the judge were there alone.

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee
context.text: On page 5 it does of the transcript, it does not indicate who was present.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Alright then, if it doesn't indicate who was present, why isn't the situation exactly like the hypothetical that Mr. Justice Goldberg just stated?

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Now in this case, you say that the record does not show who was there and I suppose we're entitled to consider that just the two of them were and why would it be different in that respect?

context.speaker: Francis C. Lee

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Would you comment in reference to the question of Justice Brennan asked you about who the burden was and the interest?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: Would you comment on the statistics on page 6 of the yellow grid, appellee's brief which apparently were furnished by the Post Office in which are the actual experience under this statute?

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: Well, we think it's clear and the one thing that this Court's decision, since 1954 and indeed we think 1937, made it clear that where the state inserts race in the statute and -- and the offense or lack of offense depends upon the race of the party, that clearly violates the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: And, we think that that is a question that is just -- ought to be beyond argument at this day in the Court.

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: But getting back, Mr. Justice Stewart, to the product -- I mean, to the Pace case, as we understand it, there, what the state did was to make a different penalty if the parties were of a different race.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The reasoning of the Court, at least part of the reasoning of the Court in the Pace case was the same as that suggested in Mr. Justice Harlan's question yesterday.

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: That is, that both the Negro and the White person were punished equally, neither one was discriminated against in the --

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: I'm not abandoning the -- Mr. Pollak will argue the anti-miscegenation, we're not abandoning that, but we do think that it's so clear on so many different grounds that this conviction must be versed -- reversed.

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: That the one I am pressing now is the one suggested by Mr. Justice Brennan, namely because the statute refers to race, the bite of the statute is race, that every decision of this Court is necessarily unconstitutional.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Just one last question, if I may, Mr. Coleman.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The -- that the state did not proved the element of the offense, you argued that -- as Mr. Justice Clark suggested, that also it has a problem with the definition of Negro and color.

context.speaker: William T. Coleman, Jr.
context.text: Yes, sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now, I gather -- do I correctly understand that argument that this is really a buoy kind of vagueness.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: Thus the boundary having been established in 1943 between the State of Nebraska and the State of Iowa by compact placing it in the center of the design channel, the boundary is there.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: It only must be physically located.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: This Court can do nothing more to determine the location of that line.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: In view of the argument that you're making now, I don't understand the answer you gave to Justice Brennan or Justice White that you did not regard the question of Nebraska having no interest in this land as such itself as a state was dispositive of the original jurisdiction question.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: And not entirely.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: I intended to convey that the lack of ownership in the land by the State of Nebraska as an -- as a sovereign entity precludes it from having any interest to invoke original jurisdiction as to the location of the boundary line.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: Thus the boundary having been established in 1943 between the State of Nebraska and the State of Iowa by compact placing it in the center of the design channel, the boundary is there.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: It only must be physically located.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: This Court can do nothing more to determine the location of that line.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: In view of the argument that you're making now, I don't understand the answer you gave to Justice Brennan or Justice White that you did not regard the question of Nebraska having no interest in this land as such itself as a state was dispositive of the original jurisdiction question.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: And not entirely.

context.speaker: Mr. Attorney General
context.text: I intended to convey that the lack of ownership in the land by the State of Nebraska as an -- as a sovereign entity precludes it from having any interest to invoke original jurisdiction as to the location of the boundary line.

context.speaker: Richard L. Jones
context.text: Or -- I'll point it out this way, take a note --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Jones, I heard that the (Inaudible) along your argument that --

context.speaker: Richard L. Jones
context.text: Alright sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: -- its one corner though, in your colloquy with Justice Goldberg, were you suggesting this that somehow for the reasons that you've been outlining, this administrative remedy either was a useless one whether for -- or other reasons that any event in the circumstances because it was an unfair kind of procedure you had to resort to it too quickly or you had to make elections which gave you a Hobson's choice that on that account this was not the kind of a procedure to which you had to resort even if ordinarily under the principles of our cases as a matter of federal law, you would have to (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: Richard L. Jones
context.text: No sir.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Is that right?

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But here you're about to (Inaudible).

context.speaker: William R. Bagby
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And maybe (Inaudible) Justice Clark, the judges dispute (Inaudible) discussion for a fraud.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: That is still (Inaudible) --

context.speaker: William R. Bagby
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So you -- that's your first -- that's your first point on that (Inaudible) that it makes no difference whatsoever with the statute of limitations (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Bruce J. Terris
context.text: That's right Your Honor.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: (Inaudible)

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Does your case depend on this finding with you on that point?

context.speaker: Robert C. Ward
context.text: Well Your Honor, my case depends upon this Court extending the doctrine of divisible divorce to determine what Florida did was this, they have ruled that this woman cannot later, after this man dies and when this right of dower then becomes choate cannot come in and assert the New York decree.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: I understand that.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: What I was -- what I was wondering is, does your case depend on the answer you just gave to Justice White namely that this was -- was not a proper divorce?

context.speaker: Robert C. Ward

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But he would still be bigamist when he remarry?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The --

context.text: Yes sir, they did.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: On what theory did you seize -- Mr. Justice Black's dissenting opinion?

context.speaker: James E. Barlow
context.text: Well, I wasn't in charge of the seizure --

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: No, I did not --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: (Inaudible)
(Inaudible)

context.speaker: Hawthorne Phillips
context.text: I'm not familiar with that word.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: My question was directed (Inaudible) what Justice Black (Inaudible), this was the (Inaudible) there's no question the book, "concerned in the affirmation of the Communist party affect -- based upon the interest (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: At least it doesn't have to (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And that don't shift your answer to what Justice Black (Inaudible) in this area, (Inaudible) that this law concerns (Inaudible) and other things.

context.speaker: Hawthorne Phillips
context.text: I'm not familiar with that word.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: My question was directed (Inaudible) what Justice Black (Inaudible), this was the (Inaudible) there's no question the book, "concerned in the affirmation of the Communist party affect -- based upon the interest (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: At least it doesn't have to (Inaudible).

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: And that don't shift your answer to what Justice Black (Inaudible) in this area, (Inaudible) that this law concerns (Inaudible) and other things.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: But then that the books (Inaudible) of others, will he -- would he (Inaudible)?

context.speaker: Hawthorne Phillips
context.text: Theoretically, the officer was supposed to seize books relating to the Communist Party and his doctrines set out in the search warrant.

context.speaker: Hawthorne Phillips
context.text: I do not believe that they went into that in the court below on the hearing --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well how -- (Inaudible) --

context.speaker: Hawthorne Phillips
context.text: Because normally --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Then I don't see how you have an answer to Mr. Justice Black's question if you have to concede.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: There's no determination of that.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It was justified, the characterization of these as being used in connection with a violation of the Act.

context.speaker: Arnold Fleischmann
context.text: A very substantial --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And you think that should be eliminated?

context.speaker: Arnold Fleischmann
context.text: I'm not against profit Your Honor.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, that's what -- that's what Mr. Justice Brennan asked you.

context.speaker: Arnold Fleischmann
context.text: It isn't that I'm against the profit.

context.speaker: Arnold Fleischmann
context.text: I'm only saying that Carvel should earn its profit in a competitive market.

United Gas Improvement Company v. Contin.speaker: Justice Goldberg
United Gas Improvement Company v. Contin.case_name: United Gas Improvement Company v. Continental Oil Company
United Gas Improvement Company v. Contin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 28, 1965

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: I had just about finished when I was diverted by the lights.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: The point I was trying to make at this case in its focus on whether there was a sale in interstate commerce presents an issue that was not raised and could not have been raised in the Panhandle case.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Now, I think that -- excuse me.

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: At this point, do you think the court decision yesterday in Clay Brown dealing with sale has some relevance to this case because like Justice Douglas, a good deal of your argument about economic reality is what I mean when you just said --

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Well, I think there are two – I think that there are many differences but two seem to me particularly important.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: One is the opinion in Clay Brown was expressly recognized, that where these is some strong evidence with respect to a contrary policy of the particular statute then that may be controlling with respect to the meaning in words.

United Mine Workers of America v. Pennin.speaker: Justice Clark
United Mine Workers of America v. Pennin.case_name: United Mine Workers of America v. Pennington
United Mine Workers of America v. Pennin.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 27, 1965

context.speaker: Theodore J. St. Antoine
context.text: The purpose was to keep out very specifically the Northern Lumberman --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And if they've been organized?

context.speaker: Theodore J. St. Antoine
context.text: Even if they've been organized.

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: That's not what Justice Reed said and that's not my understanding of what I'm trying to say.

context.speaker: Theodore J. St. Antoine
context.text: Mr. Justice --

context.speaker: Tom C. Clark
context.text: We said we do not conform to the rates of wages and working conditions of this agreement and that agreement is in San Francisco area.

United State v. Boston & Maine Railroad.speaker: Justice Stewart
United State v. Boston & Maine Railroad.case_name: United State v. Boston & Maine Railroad
United State v. Boston & Maine Railroad.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 21, 1965

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It has to involve some control.

context.speaker: Edward O. Proctor, Sr.
context.text: I think it -- I think it involves an element of control or partial control.

context.speaker: Edward O. Proctor, Sr.
context.text: A control which is --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Because Mr. Justice Goldberg's hypothetical case gave you the nicest part of being a stockholder, that is, 50% of the profits is equivalent of 50% of the stock.

context.speaker: Edward O. Proctor, Sr.
context.text: That might be that it might --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The only thing it's lacking is control.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: No.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Any -- any cons -- any evidence in this to go?

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: They -- in our brief, we've related to evidence before other congressional committees.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, do you think for -- for the purposes of question Mr. Justice Goldberg has put to you that that we're -- if it's before us at all, we decide this in the context with the 1950 findings.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: Well, I don't think that -- no.

context.speaker: Archibald Cox
context.text: I -- I would think that the view was the Court was not bound by any findings or any record before the congressional committee just as congressmen were not bound by those.

context.speaker: Richard Gladstein
context.text: He has never had the chance to --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: You cannot bar me just making an argument or an inference from what is likely.

context.speaker: Richard Gladstein
context.text: Mr. Justice White, Archie Brown has never even had the chance to be -- to show what -- what he was like as an old man, and now be a new man.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Let's talk about -- let's talk about the example that Mr. Justice Goldberg gave you, not another one.

context.speaker: Richard Gladstein
context.text: Oh, well --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What about -- what about Archie Brown has been convicted to be -- and he -- and he comes in to say, “I'm a new man.

context.speaker: Joseph H. Davis
context.text: They maintained the crimes as they were and has been interpreted by this Court, and narrowly defining the various stages of this process and they attempted to remit of the impracticality of obtaining convictions by the inference of presumption.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Davis?

context.speaker: Joseph H. Davis
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Tot and these other decisions that you just submitted, the matter of reasonable of rationality based on common factual experience and early in your argument Mr. Justice Goldberg asked you a question, which I think you didn't answer, because I think you weren't given an opportunity to answer, there's another question, but I'd like to ask you again.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In common experience, what other people would be at a still except those connected with the operation of it?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Now, I grant you, I can understand the lost aviator who is parachuted or the mountain climber or the fisherman, but --

context.speaker: Joseph H. Davis
context.text: We're dealing with a series of circumstances which branches out into several.

context.speaker: Joseph H. Davis
context.text: And if he can be innocent of one and guilty of the other to infer that mere presence go this way as opposed to that way is a strained inference indeed.

context.speaker: Joseph H. Davis
context.text: Thank you, sir.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Now you didn't quite answer Justice Brennan's question.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: I didn't quite get it --

context.speaker: Joseph H. Davis
context.text: About the evidence on the --

context.speaker: Arthur J. Goldberg
context.text: I believe that the statutes submit direct suits against the State or doesn't it, without depending on the individual.

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: But the thing that is being corrected is individual action.

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: It can't constitutionally be otherwise.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But the case that you've made parties on what Mr. Justice Goldberg said and they pay.

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: To the extent that they -- that the State, qua state is said to be acting unconstitutionally or wrongfully.

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: It can't be squared with the Constitution.

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: The only action of the sovereign would have been that it held the title if the suit was well taken.

context.speaker: Hugo L. Black
context.text: Yes, if your -- if that ground is solid, that is a distinction.

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Mr. Clark, I didn't -- I don't quite remember your answer to Justice White when he asked you if you are arguing that Section 1971 is unconstitutional to the extent that it authorizes a proceeding instituted by the Attorney General against the State.

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: Do you consider it's unconstitutional?

context.speaker: Charles Clark
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, if your conception of join under that statute --

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Greenawalt
context.text: Whatever his religion under the First Amendment, they've got to conform to that.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Greenawalt
context.text: Yes, that's my position.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Greenawalt
context.text: Now what is not religion under the First Amendment, is another story.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But what Justice Stewart's question was does any exemption have to cover every belief, not only religious belief, but other beliefs that are protected under the First Amendment.

context.speaker: Kenneth W. Greenawalt
context.text: I would say either --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Either political or moral --

context.speaker: Frank I. Goodman
context.text: What I’ve suggested is that he was an investigator.

context.speaker: Frank I. Goodman
context.text: Now I suppose and I think that Mr. McCann will argue that not all investigators are reliable, but it seems to me that if one doesn’t accept his being a regular full time police officer as a sufficient indication of his reliability then the whole system breaks down because that’s the only person whoever applies for search warrant.

context.speaker: Frank I. Goodman
context.text: And if one can’t accept even the -- if one can’t accept his being an investigator is sufficient basis for believing him, then one can never believe the affiant himself.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I take it well would your answer to Mr. Justice Black be difference, if he changed this question and say this affiant made a statement, an undercover man told me everything that Justice Black said, would that be a different case?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: He just stopped with an undercover man told me.

context.speaker: Frank I. Goodman
context.text: Instead of an investigator told me.

Warren Trading Post Company v. Arizona T.speaker: Justice White
Warren Trading Post Company v. Arizona T.case_name: Warren Trading Post Company v. Arizona Tax Commission
Warren Trading Post Company v. Arizona T.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 09, 1965

context.speaker: Earl Warren
context.text: That posture as I understand it was this, sales by Indian traders to non-Indians taxable, sales by Indian traders to Indians not taxable.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well then, why isn't that the end of the -- why shouldn't that be the end of the argument without you ever having to get to Indian commerce or preempt or anything like that?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: If the Buck Act doesn't cover this, does it permit this tax?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Why shouldn't it be as Mr. Justice Brennan says, considered to be a tax on a trader in California?

context.speaker: Edward Jacobson
context.text: Our position on the Buck Act Mr. Justice White is that it was not intended to affect the Indian reservations and so I would have to accede that if the State of Arizona otherwise had the power to tax Indian of sales to Indians on the reservation, the Buck Act wouldn't prevent it.

context.speaker: Edward Jacobson
context.text: And so I have to then show that it doesn't otherwise have the power after showing the Buck Act does not give it that power.
